prompts.text: What is remifentanil and how does it differ from other opioids?
expectedKeyFacts: Ultra-short-acting synthetic opioid
μ-opioid receptor agonist
Metabolised by non-specific plasma and tissue esterases
Context-sensitive half-time remains constant (~3-4 minutes) regardless of infusion duration
Inactive metabolites — no accumulation

prompts.text: Explain the pharmacokinetic properties that make remifentanil unique.
expectedKeyFacts: Ester linkage rapidly hydrolysed by non-specific esterases
Metabolism is independent of hepatic or renal function
Small volume of distribution (~0.3 L/kg)
Very high clearance (~40 mL/kg/min)
Rapid redistribution and elimination
No active metabolites
Predictable offset even after prolonged infusion

prompts.text: A patient with severe renal failure requires a major operation. How would you use remifentanil in this context and why?
expectedKeyFacts: Remifentanil is ideal for renal failure — ester metabolism is independent of renal function
No dose adjustment required
Avoids accumulation seen with morphine and fentanyl metabolites
Predictable offset allows rapid titration
Must plan alternative analgesia before discontinuation
No residual analgesia after stopping infusion

prompts.text: What are the potential problems when using remifentanil for anaesthesia?
expectedKeyFacts: Profound bradycardia — especially with rapid bolus
Chest wall rigidity at high doses
Profound respiratory depression — requires mechanical ventilation
Acute opioid tolerance — may require higher doses intraoperatively
Hyperalgesia post-infusion — increased postoperative pain
No residual analgesia — must transition to alternative analgesia before emergence
Expensive compared to alternatives

prompts.text: When would you choose remifentanil over fentanyl or alfentanil?
expectedKeyFacts: Cases requiring rapid, predictable emergence (neurosurgery, awake craniotomy)
Renal or hepatic impairment — avoids accumulation
Total intravenous anaesthesia (TIVA) — stable plasma levels
Cases with uncertain duration — no accumulation concern
Controlled hypotension — easily titrated
Acknowledge disadvantages: cost, need for transition analgesia, potential hyperalgesia
Fentanyl preferred for long cases with residual analgesia requirement

rescuePrompt: Perhaps you could tell me about the side effects of remifentanil — what do you see when you give an induction dose?
keyFacts: Metabolised by plasma and tissue esterases
Context-sensitive half-time ~3-4 minutes regardless of duration
Independent of hepatic and renal function
Chest wall rigidity at high doses
No residual analgesia — requires transition plan
Ideal for TIVA, neurosurgery, renal failure

scoringGuidance.pass: Correctly identifies ester metabolism and esterase-mediated breakdown, explains constant context-sensitive half-time, discusses advantages in renal failure, aware of bradycardia and hyperalgesia risks, can justify choice vs other opioids; stronger candidates explain three-compartment model and transition analgesia strategies
scoringGuidance.borderline: Knows remifentanil is short-acting and metabolised differently but vague on mechanism, mentions some side effects, unclear on clinical applications or when to prefer over alternatives
scoringGuidance.fail: Cannot explain unique pharmacokinetics, unaware of ester metabolism, does not understand clinical implications of ultra-short duration, no knowledge of hyperalgesia or transition analgesia requirement
